title: 180 KG of a mixture of milk and water contains 5% water. How much more water should be added to it so that water may be 10% in the mixture? - Quora

response.answer_text: Weight of Milk present in milk-water mixture containing 5% water= 180 x 0.95 =171 kg. If the milk-water mixture should contain 10% water, then amount of water to be added is 'V' then 171= (180 + V) x 0.9 solving the equation we get 171= 162 + 0.9V So V= 9/0.9= 10 kg. So on adfing 10 kg of Water, to 180 kg of milk-water mixture containing 5% water will be diluted to a mixture containing 10% water or 90% milk.
10 kilos. You start with 180Kg of mixture, of which 5% (that is, 9 kilos) is water. By adding 10Kg of water, you end up with 190Kg of mixture, of which 19Kg (10%) is water.

You know there are consumer laws that prohibit such activity. ‘Watering-down’ milk is a serious offence in most states. I do hope you are not trying to get the good folks on Quora involved in illegal activity! This question should be removed.
